list_definition.definition: (often with up, on etc) to put together or connect

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The electrician joined the wires (up) wrongly
You must join this piece (on) to that piece
He joined the two stories together to make a play
The island is joined to the mainland by a sandbank at low tide.

list_definition.definition: to connect (two points) eg by a line, as in geometry

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: Join point A to point B.

list_definition.definition: to become a member of (a group)

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: She was thinking of joining the tennis club.

list_definition.definition: (sometimes with up) to meet and come together (with)

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: This lane joins the main road
Do you know where the two rivers join?
They joined up with us for the remainder of the holiday.

list_definition.definition: to come into the company of

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: I’ll join you later in the restaurant.

list_definition.definition: a place where two things are joined

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: You can hardly see the joins in the material.

list_ex_of_english: Some returned to join another garden on a false identity.
The immigrants insisted that others should join them at their earliest opportunity.
The other performers then joined in with brief exchanges to illustrate this cold and wounding behaviour.
When the occasion arose and the interviewee permitted, we were able to have a group of the subject's peers join a conversation.
However, this more general rule is incompatible with the existence of joins which are needed for sums, as described above.
One approach is for those ethnically-based parties most willing to compromise to join together and, by joining, to fend off the uncompromising extremes.
The number of new walkers joining each month remained stable for the first 8 months of the scheme.
About 60 other parties also joined the electoral contest, both within and outside the major contending alliances.
